sentence: Introduction
Different substances are all around us, and can have a very large impact on individuals’ lives. It seems fairly common in our world to drink alcohol, smoke, or use drugs
Especially being an undergrad in college, it’s interesting to see just how prevalent these substances are within the “college bubble
However, substances can undoubtedly have a huge impact on people’s lives; when I consider such an impact, it is usually negative as well
For this research, we are interested in the possible associations which may exist between one’s sex and substance-usage habits
Through our three scenarios and hypotheses tests, we explore the relationship between sex and drinking, smoking, and drug habits
Data
The data for this project was gathered via a volunteered sample from San Francisco OKCupid Users
The sample size consists of 1,500 individuals who were active on 06/30/2012 and had active accounts on 06/26/2012
The data consists of 17 different variables
our research will focus on 4 of these variables

The relevant variables include sex (m/f), drinks (very often, often, socially, rarely, desperately, not at all), smokes (yes, sometimes, when drinking, trying to quit, no), and drugs (never, sometimes, often)
In order to visualize the relevant distributions of these 4 variables, the following figures (figure 1, figure 2, figure 3, and figure 4) are bar graphs of our variables
From these separate data distributions, the following research scenarios/hypotheses will aim to explore the possible relationships which may exist between sex and drinking, smoking, and drugs habits
However, it is important to note a few issues within the data
The first aspect to note is that sex is defined as either male or female, thus working from a biological perspective distinguished from sex
Secondly, the data was obtained via a volunteered sample, therefore, our findings could be biased
In this report, we are interested in exploring whether an association exists between sex and drinking habits, using drugs, or smoking habits
The first possible relationship we will discuss is between sex and drinking habits
We hypothesize that there will be a relationship between sex and drinking habits
Our null and alternative hypotheses are as follows
H0: There is no association between sex and drinking habits (sex and drinking habits are independent)
Ha: There is an association between sex and drinking habits (sex and drinking habits are dependent)
Before formally testing the hypothesis, we will compare the differences in proportions between these three categorizations within the drinking variable among males and females
The following figure displays a contingency table for proportion for each group
We can observe from this table that males have higher proportions within every single drinking category
These differences in proportion informally suggest a relationship between sex and drinking habits
Additionally, we assess our hypotheses with a formal inference for contingency tables
Because we are exploring the relationship between a categorical explanatory and a categorical response variable, the Chi-Square Test is the appropriate test to use
In order to use the Chi-Square Test, a number of formal assumptions must be met
First, we must be using contingency table data
Because we are looking at a categorical explanatory (male/female) and categorical response variable (not at all, often, socially), we use a contingency table
Second, the categories must be independent
Because each individual is only in one cell of the table, we know that our categories are independent
Additionally, 3 more conditions must be met to justify the Chi-Square Test
First, the data must be gathered randomly
Although this data set came from a volunteered sample, we will assume that it is reasonably random for the sake of our research
Secondly, we must have statistically independent measures within each cell
Because our population is large, we can safely assume our measures are independent
Lastly, we must have sufficient size for each expected cell-count (at least 5)
Calculating the expected cell counts, we find that not every single cell has at least 5
However, the study could easily combine categories in order to account for this
Since our assumptions are met (for the most part), we carry out our test at alpha=0.05
Our Chi-Square Test produces a test statistic of Chi-Sq=2.9442, and a p-value of 0.8158

Since the p-value is greater than 0.05, we fail to reject the null hypothesis that there is no association between sex and drinking habits, and conclude that there is not sufficient evidence for a relationship between sex and drinking habits
Although we have not confirmed there to be a relationship between sex and drinking habits, we are interested in exploring a different possible relationship: sex and smoking habits
We hypothesize that there will be an association between sex and smoking habits
Our null and alternative hypotheses are as follows
H0: There is no association between sex and smoking habits (sex and smoking habits are independent)
Ha: There is an association between sex and smoking habits (sex and smoking habits are dependent)
Before formally testing the hypothesis, we will compare the differences in proportions between the categorizations within the smoking variable among males and females
The following figure displays a contingency table for proportion for each group
As did the first contingency table, we can observe that males have higher proportions within every single smoking category
These differences in proportion informally suggest a relationship between sex and smoking habits
As in our first research scenario, we assess our hypotheses with a formal inference for contingency tables
Again, we are looking at the relationship between a categorical explanatory variable and a categorical response variable
Therefore, we will use the Chi-Square Test again
All of the formal conditions that must be met in order to use the Chi-Square Test have been discussed and justified in the first research question
Since our assumptions are met in the same manner as above, we carry out our test at alpha=0.05
Our Chi-Square Test produces a test statistic of Chi-Sq=7.3913, and a p-value of 0.1931

Since the p-value is greater than 0.05, we fail to reject the null hypothesis that there is no association between sex and smoking habits, and conclude that there is not sufficient evidence for a relationship between sex and smoking habits
Again, we have not confirmed there to be a relationship between sex and another response variable (smoking habits)
However, we remain interested in exploring a different possible relationship: sex and drug habits
We hypothesize that there will be an association between sex and drug habits
Our null and alternative hypotheses are as follows
H0: There is no association between sex and drug habits (sex and drug habits are independent)
Ha: There is an association between sex and drug habits (sex and drug habits are dependent)
Before formally testing the hypothesis, we will compare the differences in proportions between the categorizations within the drug variable among males and females
The following figure displays a contingency table for proportion for each group
As did the first two contingency tables, we can observe that males have higher proportions within every single drug category
These differences in proportion informally suggest a relationship between sex and drug habits
As in our first two research scenarios, we assess our hypotheses with a formal inference for contingency tables
Again, we are looking at the relationship between a categorical explanatory variable and a categorical response variable
Therefore, we will use the Chi-Square Test again
All of the formal conditions that must be met in order to use the Chi-Square Test have been discussed and justified in the first research question
We carry out our test at alpha=0.05
Our Chi-Square Test produces a test statistic of Chi-Sq=5.9983, and a p-value of 0.1117

Since the p-value is greater than 0.05, we fail to reject the null hypothesis that there is no association between sex and drug habits, and conclude that there is not sufficient evidence for a relationship between sex and drug habits
Discussion
In this project, we examine the possible relationships between sex and drinking, smoking, and drugs habits
In all three scenarios, we did not obtain p-values that were less than our alpha level (0.05)
Therefore, we failed to obtain sufficient evidence required in order to reject our null hypotheses
Research has shown that on average, men tend to drink and smoke more, and use more drugs
Although our research does not align with the evidence of a relationship between sex and substance-use habits, we could infer that our volunteered sample produced bias within the data
Future research regarding this topic would need to use random sampling in order to eliminate bias and properly justify all the conditions required in order to use the Chi-Square Test
